sanskrit_verse:
न शूद्रे पातकं किं चिन्न च संस्कारमर्हति ।
नास्याधिकारो धर्मेऽस्ति न धर्मात्प्रतिषेधनम् ॥ १०.१२६॥
transliteration:
na śūdre pātakaṁ kiṁ cin na ca saṁskāramarhati |
nāsyādhikāro dharme'sti na dharmātpratiṣedhanam || 10.126||
sph_interpretive_translation: The Śūdra neither incurs sin nor qualifies for sacraments; he has no authority in Dharma, nor can he obstruct it.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority is capacity-bound and hierarchically structured
Causation arises from alignment with one's svadharma
Capacity-based responsibility determines karmic and legal consequence
Restoration logic operates within dharma-compliant roles
Consciousness alignment is prerequisite for lawful participation
supreme_court_application: In adjudication, the court must recognize role-based capacity distinctions rooted in svadharma. A Śūdra’s actions do not incur dharmic liability or confer sacramental validity. Legal standing and authority are determined by alignment with one’s constitutional dharma, not abstract equality.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that dharmic consequence is tied to role-responsibility. As the Śūdra lacks sacramental or authoritative engagement with Dharma, no punitive or karmic consequence accrues. This reflects anupūrvaśaḥ—causality flows from alignment, not imposition. Responsibility is proportional to capacity; misalignment does not invoke retribution.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Ensure Śūdra is directed toward svadharma-aligned roles
Reintegrate individual into appropriate varna-dharma framework
Provide consciousness-alignment training to prevent future misrole assumption
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as Source of Law. Dharma is restored through alignment, not punishment. Consciousness is the ultimate adjudicator.
